div.p:
The
Tenth Annual Report
of the
Trustees and Superintendent
of the
Mississippi State Lunatic Asylum
1864

H. Hobbs Pres't
Jno. W. Robinson
Wm,,. H. Allen
W. Langley
D. N. Barrows
S. Julienne Sec
Trustees

Robert Kells Sup't and Physician
Ass't Physician
Steward
Miss Anna Stow Matron

Tenth Annual Report
of the
Superintendent of the Miss State Lunatic Asylum.
Gentleman:⁠—Permit me to offer the following, as my report touching the interest,s and the welfare of this Institution; over which you have the especial care and supervision.

Since our last communication, the Legislature has made it necessary for us to render our report on the first day of October, instead of the first of November;⁠—and hence our statement will only embrace a period of eleven months.
This change is a wise and necessary one, as it enables the Executive to consider the matter of each report, and make such notice of them in his message, as he may deem wise and salutary.
I do not entertain the belief that an extended report is at all desirable, and shall therefore only make such statements as seem proper to understand, as to the management, and the results obtained.
On the first day of November last, the asylum contained one hundred and

Tenth Annual Report
of the
Mississippi

ten patients. I have to state the results for the eleven months, to be as follows: there have been entered twelve patients; eight males and four females; making a total of one hundred twenty two under our care and treatment. There have been discharged in the same period, nineteen persons; of these eight have been "clothed in "their right mind" and restored to society and their former usefulness; one much improved, and, as I am informed, is now teaching school; two eloped, and eight have died.

The causes of death are thus registered: two of Consumption; two of convulsions; one of congestive Pneumonia; one of exhaustion from old age; one of chronic diarrhora; one of uterine haemorrhage;⁠—five of this number were females and three males. At the close of this report, there remains in the house one hundred and two inmates; and it is a melancholy fact to state, that there is not two hopeful cases of this whole num=ber. The great majority of these cases have been here; some since the house was first organized and others, from three to six years⁠—indeed in the incurable stages of insanity when brought here. This is another lamentable truth, that a very large proportion (say three fifths) of the cases brought here for treat=ment, have become hopelessly insane, for the want of proper medical care and restraint—

and the duration of the disease. It is there=fore a matter of the highest importance, to have the insane entered into the asylum in the early stages of their mental dis=order, so that the best results may be ob=tained. The mere separation from friends and familiar associations, which as a general rule are disagreeable to the insane, has a salutary influence. It is an established fact, that strangers have much more control over the feelings of the poor lunatic, than the immediate friends of the patient have. Often have I seen the patient brought here in chains, and who had been fastened down for months in this way, loossend, and require little or no restraint,⁠—and after a few days experience become entirely tractable.

The force, the appliances, and the sub=stantial character ^of every thing^ around him, makes it appear to his mind, that resistance is un—availing, and this feeling at once subdues him, to a greater or less extent.

Being among strangers, who are to govern him; who check him at every turn when guilty of acts of violence; he speedily learns not to expect that indulgence he met with at home,⁠—and very soon begets some degree of self—control, the lack of which, is the very essence of insanity.

With only a few hints here suggested in favour of early treatment in a hos-pital, properly arranged for the greatest comfort and success;⁠—it must be regarded as a great misfortune that there exists such a repugnance, generally, to give the poor lunatic, the benefit of an asylum, in the incipient stages of his malady..

I repeat it, that it is here as in purely physical diseases, that early attention is mostly successful,⁠—and I will add that very few cases of alienation of mind exist, without some degree of bodily derangement. On the contrary what do we too often painfully witness,⁠—patients brought here that are doomed to a perpet=ual bereavment of mind, and the light of reason shut out from the intellect for=ever. The motives that frequently urge friends to remove the mad man to an asylum, are not as praise—worthy as they might be.

False Pride or some less commendable motive have kept him away thus long;⁠—but now he becomes dangerous or troublesome, and emphatically beyond the hope of cure; he is ported off to an asylum, merely, for safe—keeping. Whilst patients are thus cared for, and asylums thus estimated, recoveries, will be much diminished and
the usefulness of asylums much curtailed.

I have attempted to speak earnestly upon this subject, because it is one fruitful of injury, irreparable injury, to a class that have been afflicted with the greatest of temportal calamities, and have not reason's voice, that they may be heard for their own welfare.

There have been received into the Institution, a less number, than in any former year. Four of the number or one third of the total registered; had been in the army. This dimination is contrary to public expectation, when we take into view the extraordinary events that are daily transpiring around us. The birth of this Confederacy, has brought with it a terrible baptism of blood, and has made this whole southern, sunny land, a house of mourning. It has entailed upon us, national woes, because of the loss of the brightest names in the history of our struggle; it has entailed upon us, per=sonal woes, because of the loss of friends near and dear to us; it has entailed upon ^us,^ the loss of millions of treasure, and the very structure of our society seems being destroyed.

In times of such wide—spread calamities, where the intellectual powers are being exercised to the utmost ten=sion, and the emotional faculties of our nature, stirred to their very depths;⁠—is it not truly wonderful that the mind under these extraordinary trials, should not more often be borne down into ruin and oblivion, than our observation, ex=perience, and the statistic,s of the Insti=tution would prove to be true.

I think it may ^be^ assumed as a fact, that the number of person,s that have been mentally dethroned, has been in nowise proportionate, to the universality and intensity of the action of these great and disturbing causes.

Why so few have applied for treatment, may be accounted for in part, by the fact, that our population has been greatly deminished by dis=ease from exposure in camp, and the issues of battle. Our rail-road communications have also been much interrupted, and we may suppose that other cases would have reached here, had the ordinary facilities of travel been kept up.
Why the agencies referred to, have not greatly multiplied cases of insanity, has been (as I think) owing, in some degree to the following causes. We have had since the war began,

what may be termed "healthy years,"⁠—and when the physical powers are in a healthy and normal condition, it gives a comparative immunity from mental disease. Again, the mind is daily being trained to bear and expect the losses and afflictions that follow in the track of this bloody revolution. It then seems to us, that the mind can be so prepared and fortified, as to safely endure these influ=ences; whereas, were they to occur without this probation, they would certainly over=throw the mental powers. Thirdly, it is fre=quently the case, when losses and bereavement overtake us, that the ^mind^ will be ^to some extent^ more at life pre—occupied with the higher duties, and un—accustomed responsibilities, incident to such losses and bereavement. Thus may the natural feelings of grief and sorrow, be abated, to the great relief of the mind,⁠—and perhaps influences of a lower and more pernicious character be supplanted.

This subject is certainly worthy of some notice in a report of this kind, and I have thought proper to offer a few sugg=estions, though brief and crude they may be. There is a philosophy in every thing around us, and it is the part of wisdom and of duty, to gather every practical lesson that it teaches.

In the beginning of the year, the opinion generally obtained here, that the federals would occupy and garrison Jackson. In such an event, something must be done to provide for our charge, as our money would ^be^ discredited, as soon as we were with=in the enemy,s lines. I consulted the Trustees as far as I could, and suggested the propriety of purchasing cotton to the full extent of our means. This I believe met with their ready approval, and I accordingly purchased fifty bales of cotton at thirty five cents per pound.

The sum required for this purchase was seven thousand, Seven hundred and fifty seven dollars and five cents. Fifty two bales more, came into the possession of the asylum in the following manner. The transaction can be better understood by giving a copy of the proposition Mr Thos,, Bennett submitted to me.
Copy

On or about the first of February last, I did propose to give Dr Robert Kells or the Lunatic Asylum one half interest in one hundred and twenty eight bales of cotton⁠—if he, the said Kells would remove the same to the Asylum, for safe-keeping. I furthermore state, that only one hundred and four bales of cotton were dilivered to the said Kells, or the Lunatic asylum under this prop=osition.
Thos Bennett

Signed
M. Brady
for Bennett
Jackson Miss
Aug 13th,,/64
When Mr Bennett made this proposal to me, I told him, I would pass over this cotton for the benefit of the asylum and not accept it for myself.

Under this generous proffer, I removed the cotton with as little delay as possible, as Sherman with his army, was expected in Jackson every day. I could not give this matter my personal attention, and I thought until about the first of August, that the one hundred and twenty eight bales had been moved, and so reported to the Board at the time. When I found out that only one hundred and four had been sent, I thought it necessary to get the above state=ment as copied from Mr Bennett.
I wrote to Gen Polk, stating to him what I had done, and desired him to protect the cotton. This matter touched his benevolent heart, and he at once issued the necessary orders, for its safety.

In my correspondence with Gov Clark, I opened my views to him, as to the necessity of making some arrangement to carry cotton through the lines, and obtain such things as were absolutely needed for the comfort and well-being of the inmates,⁠—and that ^it^ was out of our power and beyond our means to get in the Confederacy. Gov Clark acted promptly in furtherance of this object, and obtained a permit from Gen S. D. Lee, commander

of this military department, to carry one hundred and fourteen bales of cotton through the lines, and exchange for supplies. Under cover of this privilege I have carried thirty one bales of cotton through the lines, as far as Messengers Ferry. When I reached there, with the first loads of nineteen bales, I found some of my waggons in a condition to make it necessary to leave four bales. I made arrangement with Mrs Messenger to store this number of bales in a shed near the dwelling, where it was thought to be perfectly safe. A day or two after this Gen Slocomb made his raid out to Jackson, and a portion of his cavalry went to Messengers Ferry to destroy the flat, and a night or two afterwards the cotton was stolen, as shown you from a letter written by Mrs Messenger. So only twenty seven bales reached Vicksburg, and sold for the sum of fourteen thousand, one hundred and sixty dollars and seventy cents as pr account of sales.

The last visit I made to V.Burg I found goods rising so rapidly, owing to some new and stringent trade regulations which had just been ordered; that I thought it pru=dent to spend the whole amount of money on hand, thinking goods quite as safe as money on deposit. I knew at the time I should be unable to bring all out with me, but would return as speedily as possible

and move out what was left. The portion left, was mostly valuable dry goods, and owing to the rainy, threatening weather, I preferred to bring such things as could not be seriously injured by getting wet. A few days after I returned; I was ready to make another trip, when I was notified by Gen Adams that the lines were closed by order of Gen Maury. I then wrote to Gen Maury and explained to him the condition of the affairs of the asylum, and desired him to give me permission to go in and get these goods, as I feared that changes might occur, so as to prevent me from getting there. He thought proper not to do so, and through these orders, the patients are deprived of five thousand dollars worth, of the most valuable and most needed goods. Unless we get these purchases, I fear the patients must suffer to a greater or less extent for want of proper and comfortable clothing. I have written to Gen Dana the commander at V.Burg to learn what his purpose is, as to these goods, but have not had a suitable opportunity to send the letter. I shall pursue this matter until I learn from him, what he is ready to do in the premises.

Before I close this part of my report, I must say, I sincerely regret that more has not been accomplished in providing for our house—hold, under this arrange=ment. I can however assure the Board, that I have done the very best I could do, under the circum=-stances. The whole month of June was very wet and nothing could be done,—the month ^of July^ was one of raids and rumours of raids on the part of the Yankees, and for two weeks, there ^was^ no means of crossing the ferry; and early in August the lines were closed and have remained closed from one side or the other. The house was almost destitute of cooking utensils, of tin ware, of cutlery, of crockery ware, of med-icines, all of which we ^have^ gotten a full stock. of calicoes, summer goods for mens clothing, domestic, hats, shirts, ladies shoes, agricultural implements, groceries &c &c only a partial supply. No blankets could be bought in V.Burg, but I ordered them from N. O. through a merchant, and the stock purchased for winter clothing, as I stated before yet remain in V.Burg. The goods brought out for the asylum, could not be bought in the Confeder=acy for less than forty thousand dollars. How impossible then, to give the Institution a proper supp=ort, with anything like the present appropriation. Unless Gov Clark had kindly consented to make this arrangement for us; it would be painful to state what the consequences would be to the poor inmates.
The friends of the Institution are indebted to Gov Clark for another act of kindness,

and good-will, in turning over to the use of the Asylum, seventy four head of young beef cattle, at a cost far less than could be purchased elsewhere. Gen A. M. West has also manifested a laudable interest in our behalf, and has our thanks for favours.

I feel it my duty to remind the Trustees that the amount due Dr J. S. Sizer has not been paid yet. On the 22nd,, day of December 1863, in the presence of a proper witness, I tendered to pay him in Confederate or State issue, the sum due, on a certain note given for the purchase of a tract of woodland. This ^purchase^ has proved a fortunate and saving transaction to the Insti=tution, as the amount of wood already cut and hauled to the grounds, could not be laid down here, for less than twenty thousand doll=ars. Not more than one half of the timber has yet been felled.

Many repairs are needed inside and outside of the Institution;—but the enormous ex=pense of labour and material, place it beyond our means to attend to them. Such as are indispensable, we do not fail to have them looked after. About two thousand dollars out of our appropriation, has been paid alone, on our gas and heating apparatus during the year.

Our garden and field labour has again been blest with good, and many instances, with boun=tiful results. I must state to the credit of the patients, that much of this labour is performed by them. We have quite a number of chronic cases, that are in pretty good, and some in robust health, that engage in these health=ful employments. The female patients also make themselves useful in their department, and the result of their labours, spares no little expense to the Institution. All the clothing for males and females have been made up in the house, beside many other pieces, of which the number has not been kept,—for until re=cently, we have had no matron whose province it is to attend to this matter. I still perform the duties of assistant Physician and Steward, and trust that the Board may have reason to be satisfied.

This has been a year full of trials and difficulties, and has greatly increased my cares and responsibility, as the chief officer of the Institution. Notwithstanding the many embarrassments, I have not ceased to labour, singly, to give character and success to this noble charity of the State.

I cannot let this occasion pass, without tendering to Dr Poindexter, and the other members of the committee on the Lunatic Asylum, my good—wishes, for the very kind and complimentary report they thought proper to make, affecting the administration and welfare of this Hospital.

In conclusion, I would not fail to express my thanks to the Board, for their kind assistance and advice in all matters of business pertaining to their office as Trustees. As our duties may become more onerous, our responsibilities greatly increase, and our trials multiplied;—let us labour endeavour to labour more earnestly and zealously, and trust to a kind Providence for good results and success.

Robert Kells,
